definitions.definition: each of the 60 parts of an hour, that are equal to 60 seconds
definitions.sensetop: minutes to…minutes past…minutes after/before…in… minutesfor… minuteswithin minutesper minute

examples.text: It's four minutes to six.
four minutes past two
five minutes after/before midnight
I'll be back in a few minutes.
Boil the rice for 20 minutes.
The ship sank within minutes.
The pump delivers seven gallons per minute.
It's only a ten-minute bus ride into town.
Two **minutes later** the phone rang.
I enjoyed every minute of the party.
The students took fifteen minutes to complete the questionnaire.
Just minutes into the second half of the game Robinson scored his second goal.
Russo scored in the 87th minute.
It takes only a few minutes to grill this fish.
He listened for a couple of minutes, then smiled.
There were two goals in the opening five minutes of the game.
After twenty minutes I started to get worried.
Fifteen minutes turned into thirty, and still no one called.
For ten agonizing minutes she couldn't find her son.
Gina wasted ten precious minutes on her final test question.
He scored in the final minutes of the game.
I spent ten minutes dealing with emails.
If you have a few spare minutes, you could clean the kitchen.
Ten long minutes later, he finally had the results.
The film starts in ten minutes.
The minutes ticked by and still nothing happened.
The noise lasted almost a full minute.
Tracey was already counting the minutes until the weekend.
We waited for ten minutes and then left.
With each passing minute, the tension mounts.
the minute hand on the clock

definitions.definition: a very short time

examples.text: It only takes a minute to make a salad.
Could you **wait a minute**, please?
**Hang on a minute**—I'll just get my coat.
I just have to finish this—I won't be a minute.
Could I see you for a minute?
I'll be with you in a minute, Jo.
Typical English weather—one minute it's raining and the next minute the sun is shining.
My brain was still working **a mile a minute** *(= very fast)*.
Can you spare a minute?
Do you have a minute, Miss Brown?
This will only take a minute.
One minute he was fine and the next minute he collapsed on the floor.

definitions.definition: an exact moment in time

examples.text: At that very minute, Tom walked in.
I've got things on my mind at the minute.

definitions.definition: each of the 60 equal parts of a degree, used in measuring angles

examples.text: 37 degrees 30 minutes (37° 30′)

definitions.definition: a summary or record of what is said or decided at a formal meeting

examples.text: We read through the minutes of the last meeting.
Who is going to **take the minutes** *(= write them)*?
I wrote up the minutes of the meeting and circulated them by email.

definitions.definition: a short note on a subject, especially one that recommends a course of action
very soon

examples.text: Hurry up! He'll be back any minute now.

definitions.definition: very fast

examples.text: Matters grew worse by the minute.

definitions.definition: a short period of being famous

examples.text: Everybody wants their fifteen minutes of fame.

definitions.definition: used to ask somebody to wait for a short time

examples.text: ‘Is Mr Burns available?’ ‘Just a second, please—I'll check.’

definitions.definition: the latest possible time before an important event

examples.text: They changed the plans at the last minute.
Don't leave your decision to the last moment.
Don't leave everything till the last minute.
Why do you leave it until the last possible moment before getting ready to leave?

definitions.definition: as soon as…

examples.text: I want to see him the minute he arrives.
The minute she walked through the door I thought she looked different.

definitions.definition: certainly not; not at all

examples.text: I don't think for a minute that she'll accept but you can ask her.
I never thought for a minute he'd refuse.

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody is very stupid
immediately; now

examples.text: Come down this minute!
I don't know what I'm going to do yet—I've **just this minute** found out.
Come here this minute!

definitions.definition: exactly

examples.text: The train arrived at 9.05 to the minute.

definitions.definition: fashionable and modern

examples.text: Her styles are always up to the minute.

definitions.definition: having the latest information

examples.text: The traffic reports are up to the minute.

definitions.definition: to wait for a short time

examples.text: Can you wait a second while I make a call?
Hey! Wait a minute! I'll come with you!

definitions.definition: used when you have just noticed or remembered something, or had a sudden idea

examples.text: Wait a minute—this isn't the right key.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: via Old French from late Latin minuta, feminine (used as a noun) of minutus ‘made small’. The senses ‘period of sixty seconds’ and ‘sixtieth of a degree’ derive from medieval Latin pars minuta prima ‘first minute part’. The sense record of a meeting is from late Middle English (in the singular in the sense ‘note or memorandum’): from French minute, from the notion of a rough copy in “small writing” (Latin scriptura minuta) as distinct from the fair copy in book hand. The verb dates from the mid 16th cent.
